Vuforia.name: Vuforia
Vuforia.description: Vuforia is an engine supported in Unity. Vuforia is its own AR tech that runs in both iOS and Android and can run on older phones. Vuforia will use ARKit/ARCore tech if the hardware will support it. Vuforia also has other advanced features like image tracking, motion planning.
Vuforia.price: Free to use, paid to publish
Vuforia.use_cases: Claims to be the most sophisticated and advanced AR content development solution
Vuforia.curstomer_segment: Largest segment is to help industrial enterprise customers address workforce challenges and meet business goals.
Vuforia.limitations: Vuforia is an old well-developed and great product. That supports the widest range of products.  There are no significant limitations of Vuforia when compare to ARCore and ARKitFor both apple and android. Costs money to publish application.

Unity3D.name: Unity3D
Unity3D.description:
Key features: Great for cross platform development, 
Language required: C# or JavaScript
One of the few great VR/AR real-time development tools
Asset store, 
Great documentation
Different rendering pipelines for different hardwares specs (HighDefinitionRenderingPipeline for AAA games and Universal Rendering Pipeline for mobile)
Friendly with many great softwares related to 3D real time development
Unity3D.related_hardwares: Windows, Mac OS, Linux Desktop, iOS, Android, Xbox, Unity Web Player, PS VR, PS3, PS4, Google Cardboard, Oculus Rift, Android TV, WiiU, SamsungTV
Unity3D.limitations:
Graphics, 
Does not allow you to load your work from a template or foundation, Licensing is annoying,
Language: C#

Wikitude SDK.name: Wikitude SDK
Wikitude SDK.description: Key features: Cloud AR, Geo AR, cross-platform with multiple language support
Wikitude SDK.price: Free trial; one-time fee: demo (499 euro), SDK Startup (499 euro), SDK Pro 3D (2490 euro); subscription: 2990+ euro

Spark AR.name: Spark AR
Spark AR.key_features: Extensive Face Tracking (with face mesh), Plane tracking, Hand Tracking (no gesture)
Spark AR.limitations: Limited hand tracking, submission requires review process, only works on Facebook and Instagram apps.

Unreal Engine.name: Unreal Engine
Unreal Engine.description:
Key features:Technical art pipeline, world building, animation, simulation, optimization
One of the few great VR/AR real-time development tools
Offers one of the best graphics in real time development
Artist friendly software (no coding required)
Language supported: C++, Blueprints(visual programming)
Unreal Engine.key_features:
Technical art pipeline, world building, animation, simulation, optimization
One of the few great VR/AR real-time development tools
Offers one of the best graphics in real time development
Artist friendly software (no coding required)
Language supported: C++, Blueprints(visual programming)
Unreal Engine.price:
Free for hobby development.
5% royalty fee after the first 3000 dollars earned for professionals.
Unreal Engine.related_hardwares: Windows, macOS, Linux, SteamOS, HTML5, iOS, Android, Nintendo Switch, PlayStation 4, Xbox One, Magic Leap One, and virtual reality (SteamVR/HTC Vive, Oculus Rift, PlayStation VR, Google Daydream, OSVR and Samsung Gear VR
Unreal Engine.limitations: No support of Vuforia, less convenient for 2D
Unreal Engine.notes: Not good for solo devs apparently

ARKit.name: ARKit
ARKit.description: Framework from Apple for building AR apps and games for iOS devices. High level API supplying powerful features for creating virtual objects. Utilizes SLAM to accurately map the surroundings.
ARKit.price: Free to use, paid to publish
ARKit.popularity: Most used framework for iOS AR applications
ARKit.limitations: Apple: “Tracking is an inexact science. It relies on details of the physical environment that aren’t always consistent or are difficult to measure in real time without some degree of error.” https://developer.apple.com/documentation/arkit/understanding_world_trackingApple devices iPhone SE, iPhone 6s and later, iPad 2017 and later, all iPad Pro models

ARCore.name: ARCore
ARCore.description: Google’s platform for building AR experiences, using different APIs ARCore enables your phone to sense its environment, understand the world and interact with information.
ARCore.use_cases: AR app building platform for Android devices.
ARCore.limitations: Supported devices: Google Pixel, Pixel XL, Pixel 2, Pixel 2 XL, Samsung Galaxy S8

Three.js.name: Three.js
Three.js.description: Three.js is a cross-browser JavaScript library and Application Programming Interface (API) used to create and display animated 3D computer graphics in a web browser.
Three.js.related_hardwares:
Three.js runs in all browsers supported by WebGL 1.0.
Android smartphone, Google Daydream, Oculus Go, Oculus Rift, Vive, Samsung Gear VR., an iPhone with a WebXR browser
Three.js.limitations: AR technology special for Three.js has not been released. AR capability relays on the 8th wall. Low level development tool in VR section. Syntax / commands keep changing

A-Frame.name: A-Frame
A-Frame.description: A-Frame is a three.js framework with an entity-component-system (ECS) architecture.
A-Frame.related_hardwares:
For browsers that support ARCore and ARKit. https://aframe.io/blog/aframe-v1.0.0/
Supports most VR headsets such as Vive, Rift, Windows Mixed Reality, Daydream, GearVR, Cardboard, Oculus Go

Snapchat/Lens Studio.name: Snapchat/Lens Studio
Snapchat/Lens Studio.key_features: facial recognition, ability for users to make their own custom filters
Snapchat/Lens Studio.limitations: lenses are only created for use on Snapchat
